title: Marco Sturm’s faith in Marat Khusnutdinov gets rewarded with Bruins OT winner
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Marat Khusnutdinov scored the overtime winner as the Boston Bruins defeated the Buffalo Sabres 4-3.
Coach Marco Sturm promoted Khusnutdinov to the Bruins' top line, resulting in a standout performance.
Khusnutdinov logged significant ice time after Elias Lindholm's injury, contributing defensively and offensively.

title: Why Dan Orlovsky believes Drake Maye is NFL MVP frontrunner
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Drake Maye leads the Patriots to a 6-2 start, completing 75.2% of passes with 15 TDs and 3 interceptions.
Dan Orlovsky supports Maye's NFL MVP candidacy, highlighting his performance despite limited supporting talent.
Maye has the third-best odds for NFL MVP, following Patrick Mahomes and Josh Allen, according to DraftKings.

title: Brookline farm starts free farmers market as Mass. residents brace for SNAP shutdown
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Allandale Farm in Brookline is launching a free farmers market in response to the SNAP benefits threat from the government shutdown.
The market will operate on the first three Thursdays in November at the Loring Greenough House in Jamaica Plain, with Iggy's Bread donating.
Massachusetts will double aid to food banks in November, and Governor Healey has launched a new SNAP resource hub and help site.

title: $9,000 in donations stolen from Catholic church in Watertown, police say
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: $9,000 in donations stolen from St. Patrick's Church in Watertown on October 27.
The theft occurred sometime after 5:30 p.m. and was reported the next morning.
Watertown police seek information; contact Detective Joe Kelland at 617-600-1310.

title: Bruins’ Elias Lindholm exits game with lower-body injury
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Elias Lindholm suffered a lower-body injury during the Bruins' overtime win against the Buffalo Sabres on Thursday.
Lindholm collided with Sabres' Jordan Greenway, missing the rest of the game; coach Marco Sturm provided no detailed update yet.
Lindholm's potential absence poses lineup challenges; options include promoting Pavel Zacha or calling up Matt Poitras.

title: David Ortiz offers up advice to Mookie Betts amid World Series slump
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: David Ortiz advises Mookie Betts to enjoy baseball and focus on fun amid his World Series slump.
Mookie Betts struggles with a .130 average, no extra-base hits as the Dodgers trail Blue Jays 3-2.
Dodgers' top hitters, including Betts, went 1-for-15 with 8 strikeouts in Game 5 against Toronto.

title: Irish firefighter found guilty of raping woman in Boston hotel, sentenced to 7-9 years in prison
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Irish firefighter Terence Crosbie was sentenced to 7-9 years in prison for raping a woman in a Boston hotel.
Crosbie was found guilty of raping the woman, who was sleeping, during a visit for St. Patrick’s Day.
The jury reviewed key card, DNA evidence, and video footage; Crosbie plans to appeal, claiming a miscarriage of justice.

title: Brockton man allegedly in US illegally sentenced to prison for raping 14-year-old girl
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Erickson Barbosa, 32, pleaded guilty to raping a 14-year-old in 2020 and was sentenced to seven years in state prison.
Barbosa, originally from Cape Verde, will also serve five years of probation and may face deportation after his sentence.
Barbosa, who was illegally in the U.S., was arrested by U.S. Marshals in Florida and extradited to Massachusetts.

title: ‘Special stuff’: Why Patriots CB Marcus Jones’s October was one to remember
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Marcus Jones received the AFC Defensive Player of the Month award and signed a three-year contract extension with the Patriots.
Jones excelled in October, securing key plays including an interception against the Bills and a sack, contributing significantly to defense.
In special teams, Jones scored a pivotal 87-yard punt return touchdown against the Panthers, ranking third in NFL punt return yards.

title: Dartmouth man pleads guilty to 2024 murder of New Bedford woman
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Tyler Baglini pleaded guilty to murdering Kerri Fidalgo in September 2024 in New Bedford, receiving life with parole after 25 years.
Fidalgo was found with multiple stab wounds, and Baglini arrived at the hospital holding a stained knife, claiming she was stabbed.
Baglini's previous offenses include assault and domestic abuse, highlighted during the sentencing in Fall River Superior Court.
